course.title: Blender Character Creator v2.0 for Video Games Design
course.subtitle: Model Video Game Characters. Use The Sculpt Tool To Shape, Add Texture, Rig & Animate Video Game Characters

reviews.body:
The course is for beginners and it is really well made. The best thing about it is that it covers every aspect of creation.

A couple of notes: it covers how to add animations to a character (But it doesn't cover how to animate it yourself); it shows how to do retopology (But it doesn't go into the details of doing it the proper way).

Regarding the notes, animation and retopology would be courses on their own. But you'll leave this course knowing about them.

I highly recommend the course. In fact, I also bought it for my sister as a gift.

Huge fan of Grant Abbitt. I've been following his videos for a little while now. When I saw that he was part of the revamp of this course, I nearly lost my nerd-loving mind! Keep up the good work Game Dev. You guys rock!!

Grant is one of the best teachers on this site. I kept trying to pick up Blender but could not learn it until this course taught by Grant. The way he constantly says the keyboard shortcuts as he is doing his work helped me tremendously to remember them.

The course is a streamlined workflow from a basic knowledge of Blender to having a sculpted, animated, textured character, plus getting all of those things into Unity set up with an animation controller, and this it does very well. Retopology and rigging are covered enough to get you to the end but not explored in minute detail, and I'll be looking to perfect these next, as well as learn more about hair and clothing.

Very detailed and insightful course. I learned a lot from it. And finally I could create something that looks like a convincing character.

A little short though on animations part. But there are plenty of lectures in the archived version of the course, so it's okay.

Well, what I love about this course is how Grant teaches. He is a humble person and you can see he has a passion for what he is doing and teaching others.

In this course, I'm learning how to better understand Blender and his functions (Shader Nodes, Modifiers, etc..), and plus you will have new ideas on how to create a character for your own projects.

I'm a newbie on this stuff about game dev. and game design but I'm very interested to get a job related to this, in the future.
Really enjoyed the course and given me the confidence to make my own characters. Definitely recommend it to anyone considering character creation.

I really liked the course, I will gladly take another course in the future of GameDevTv. Very good explanations, time allows you to follow the videos well, very well all the stages of the project. The instructor gives good tips to get the job done faster

Created some great looking models in no time. Everything you need to know. Straight to the point. No faff. Amazing!

Finally I have just finished this course. There are a lot of videos to watch and concepts to understand, but Grant is a great teacher. The pace gets a bit quick toward the end and I missed a few points that cost me time later, having to go back and review videos to find out where I went wrong. Everything made sense in the end though. A create overview of the workflow required to create your own animated game assets or simply 3D models if that's your bag.

Last part of the course is dissapointing, heavily packed up into few ~15min clips, chaotic, with scraps of information, without proper and decent explanation - prepared seemingly carelessly. Overall course is informational, some parts are explained carefully, learning flow is in a good shape. UV unwrapping could be a little bit more informational because of additional complexity of a subject.

Kinda informational, up to the point of texturing model is decent. Unity part seems like a bad joke and looking at the level of commitment and preparation it would be better to not include it at all.

I do not know if I will ever be able praise this course enough. I have been drawing characters for video games for as long as I can remember. This game has helped me achieve my childhood dream of creating my first video game character. I have dabbled in Blender for years but felt I lacked the right guidance to see a character design through. Not only was the curriculum well thought out, but the encouragement from these instructors was phenomenal. The small exercises thrown in were a terrific touch and really gave the student an opportunity to explore their own method for modeling/sculpting before following the technique of a skilled mentor. Thank you for helping me to fulfill a long sought after goal!

I was quite disheartened when I realized that Michael Bridges wasn't teaching this course. He did an absolutely fantastic job for the GameDev.TV Beginner Blender course. At first, I was a bit unsure about Grant's instruction (I'll get to why), but, I must admit that I ended up learning quite a lot, from him, and have really grown fond of him, towards the end of this course. He does a really great job during the sculpting section of the course and I'm extremely happy with how my skills and knowledge have advanced, thanks to him and the GameDev.TV team.

Now, my one major bone to pick... Please, please, PLEASE be better about encouraging good (and proper!) practices--like naming your objects and applying your transforms whenever scaling/rotating in Object Mode. Without naming objects, it can be a bit hard to follow along; and applying transforms would really cut down on a lot of problems that arise. At a point, Grant states naming objects (or not) as "the difference between artists and game devs". That's a bit insulting. The reality is that it's the difference between an amateur and a professional. I don't think ANYONE in the industry would be happy to have to deal with a model with parts called: Cube.001, Plane.004. So, please set a better example for students and follow good practices. It's really not that hard and really doesn't take that much extra time.

Sorry for the TLDR rant, but even teachers need a teaching, from time to time.

We have more than 600,000 students, and our aim is to make and maintain high quality courses that are engaging and entertaining for them.

GameDev tv offers comprehensive courses on Unity, Blender, Unreal, coding in C#, C++ and more.  Looking to learn about a topic that we don't cover? Get plugged into our communities of amazing developers on Facebook (nearly 20k), in our own TA-curated Community (17k views/day), and our student chat group (10k live at any one time).
